Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Life at the ocean surface: evolution and morphology of the Portuguese man of war
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Portuguese man-of-war, Physalia physalis, drifts at the ocean surface. It is highly specialized for this environment using a gas-filled float as a sail to catch the wind and long tentacles as fishing line to capture small fishes and crustaceans. Physalia physalis is known to many beach goers for its painful sting, but despite being familiar and abundant, little is known about most basic features of this species. In this project, researchers will use new microscopy techniques to answer old questions about the anatomy, development, and evolutionary origins of this unique species. The products of this study will be made freely accessible to the public and other scientists via open access publishing. The award will also support lessons in a local elementary school on topics related to this project, including lessons on ocean zones, plankton, pleuston, and marine invertebrate body plans.

Physalia physalis is the only siphonophore (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa) that is pleustonic (living at the interface between water and air). Siphonophores are colonial animals that are composed of zooids (bodies) that are each homologous to solitary animals. This project will describe fundamental features of P. physalis morphology and use phylogenetic comparative methods to reconstruct the evolutionary changes associated with a transition from a planktonic to pleustonic lifestyle. The primary product of this work will be a re-description of P. physalis, which also aims to address some of the following questions: how are zooids organized in P. physalis? How does P. physalis zooid morphology and colony organization differ from other siphonophore species, and what does this suggest about their evolution? Physalia physalis colonies have highly 3-dimensional branching structures. Optical Projection Tomography, as well as other immuno-fluorescent imaging methods, will be used to 3D-image fixed P. physalis tissue. These morphological descriptions will be compared with morphological descriptions available for planktonic siphonophores in order to investigate general patterns of character evolution within the siphonophore phylogeny.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Portuguese man of war, Physalia physalis, is a member of the pleuston, a community of organisms that float at the ocean surface. It is also a siphonophore, a group of relatively misunderstood colonial animals that are found from the ocean surface to the deep sea. Physalia physalis has a very unusual body plan and structure, as compared to other siphonophores, in part due to its unique lifestyle floating at the ocean surface. It has a gas-filled float that it uses as a sail to harness the power of the wind, and drags long tentacles that are used to kill and capture fish. The Portuguese man of war is colonial, meaning that it consists of many different bodies, and each of these bodies is specialized to a particular function (e.g feeding, reproducing). In most siphonophores, the different bodies are organized in a very precise manner along a linear stem, but the Portuguese man of war has a more complex branching structure and colony arrangement.

One of the main goals of this project was to redescribe Physalia physalis, to improve our understanding of the morphology of this species, and to reconstruct the evolutionary changes associated with a transition to a lifestyle that consists of floating on the ocean surface. To do this, we carried out field collections along the coast of Galveston Island, TX, and also obtained young, developing specimens from the collection of a collaborator. In addition to microscopy and photography of live specimens, we used optical projection tomography as a tool to investigate the 3D structure and colonial organization. We also obtained gene expression profiles of the different zooid types.

This work combined phylogenetic comparative methods with microscopy techniques to identify changes in the growth, development and arrangement of zooids that are associated with a transition from a life living in the water column to a life spent on the ocean surface. One of the products of this work was a paper that addresses the phylogenetic relationships of siphonophores, and uses phylogenetic comparative methods to address the evolution of a number of different traits within this group. These results, including data collected through this project were also presented at the annual SICB conference in 2018. The redescription of the Portuguese man of war, featuring 3D images, is currently being prepared. In this redescription, we clarify aspects of the colonial organization of this species throughout its lifecycle, and in particular, the origin of one specialized body that is found only in this species - the tentacle bearing body, which we call the tentacular palpon. This body does not have the ability to feed, and has one very long tentacle. We suggest, agreeing with hypotheses proposed in 1888 by Ernst Haeckel (and subsequently rejected), that this body is a reduced, derived feeding body.

This project supported the dissertation chapter and independent research of a female graduate student (co-PI Catriona Munro), providing an important training opportunity. Additionally, funds from this project were used to support an after school science club in East Providence, RI. In addition to several classes on topics directly related to this topic (ocean zones, plankton and microscopy), funds were also used to provide much needed supplies, including folding microscopes, USB microscopes and lab notebooks, which will continue to be used for future classes.
